risinfo.booktitle: Companion Animal End of Life Care for the Veterinary Technician

sect1.title: 1 Introduction to Animal Hospice and Palliative Care

para.emphasis: Veterinary Technology Program, Dalhousie University, Bible Hill, NS, Canada

sect2.title: 1.1 Introduction
sect2.para: The foundational philosophy of animal hospice and palliative care (AHPC) requires a perspective shift from traditional veterinary practice. It is more often about the approach to care than specific medicine and nursing techniques. Animal hospice embraces life in the face of death such that dying patients and their loved ones live life to the fullest until the moment of death. Animal hospice aims to improve and maintain quality of life (QOL) throughout the end‐of‐life (EOL) journey while also supporting the human–animal bond. This continues until the time of death and beyond, with a focus on quality of dying and a meaningful EOL transition for the animal and their loved ones.

EOL care has always been a part of veterinary medicine, but it is relatively recent that AHPC has emerged as a dedicated area of study and practice. The roots of human hospice date back centuries, and modern human hospice has its origins in the 1960s. By contrast, AHPC is a young discipline, beginning in the 1980sch0011-c1-bib-0001 with 2009 marking the founding of the International Association of Animal Hospice and Palliative Care (IAAHPC). The IAAHPC offers certification for both veterinarians and technicians and is making efforts toward establishing AHPC as a recognized veterinary specialty.

The effective provision of AHPC not only improves animal QOL and supports the human–animal bond, it also reduces caregiver decisional regret at EOL. Animal hospice or EOL care offers an opportunity to bridge the gap between care provided at a veterinary facility and the potential for inadequate treatment at home or premature euthanasia due to a lack of other optionsch0011-c1-bib-0001. Hospice‐supported natural death can also be offered as an alternative to euthanasia with appropriate veterinary supervision (see Chapter 9). Caregivers may feel abandoned by their veterinary teams if there is a perceived lack of treatment alternatives discussed beyond aggressive treatment and/or euthanasia ch0011-c1-bib-0002. They are often unaware of the possibilities of animal hospice, home‐based care, and hospice‐supported natural death. Offering caregivers more options and more support during the EOL period allows families to feel more in control of an unpredictable situation and remain more connected with their pet during this meaningful time.

sect2.title: 1.2 Terminology and Definitions
sect2.para: Hospice and palliative care are inseparable within the context of EOL care, but they are defined differently.Hospice is the care provided from the time of a terminal diagnosis through to the time of death, including support for the caregiver after death. Palliative care is simply the provision of non‐curative therapies that improve patient comfort. It can be offered to any patient experiencing any type of discomfort and is not restricted to EOL patients (Pro Tip 1.1). Technicians should be mindful that misconceptions about the nature of palliative care will be common among caregivers (Communication Corner 1.1).

para.emphasis: You can offer palliative care without hospice,

sect2.para: but you cannot offer hospice without palliative care.

The terms hospice and EOL care will be used interchangeably throughout this guide. It includes palliative care, hospice‐supported natural death or humane euthanasia, body care, memorialization, and grief support. In addition to prioritizing patient welfare and QOL, hospice also considers the caregiver’s needs and values. A peaceful and smooth euthanasia may be a goal for many caregivers, but it is not the ultimate measure of successful EOL care. It may be one of the goals for a particular patient, but the ultimate successful outcome is a caregiver who feels no regret in the wake of their beloved animal’s death.

There can be conflict at times between the caregiver’s perspectives and desires and the animal’s welfare, but hospice does not involve prolonging the life of the animal to help the caregiver avoid processing their grief. Hospice can involve veterinarian‐supervised, hospice‐supported natural death where euthanasia is always available if required for animal welfarech0011-c1-bib-0001. However, it must be understood that hospice does not involve natural death without supervision or intervention.

sidebar.title: Pro Tip 1.1 Palliative Care Outside of Hospice
sidebar.para: The focus of this guide is EOL care, but many of the nursing strategies discussed in Part I may be effectively applied in a palliative care program for patients that are not at the end of their life.

listitem.para: Case 1: A horse receiving massage therapy, acupuncture and pain medication while awaiting surgery for a torn ligament is receiving palliative care. Neither the massage nor the pain medication will cure the torn ligament, but both improve the patient’s comfort pre‐ and postoperatively.

Case 2: An overweight cat may struggle to groom itself and experience matting of the fur, fecal balls or urine scald around its perineal region. Grooming and hygiene management for this cat would be appropriate palliative care while a weight management program seeks to address the underlying problem.

Case 3: A miniature dachshund with hind end paresis secondary to intervertebral disc disease has an improved QOL with the use of a wheelchair for mobility and physiotherapy to preserve muscle mass and nerve function.

sidebar.para: Consider palliative care options in every patient’s individualized care. Technicians are important advocates for animals’ QOL.

sidebar.title: Communication Corner 1.1 Palliative Care Misconceptions
sidebar.para: Be mindful and intentional when using the wordpalliative outside of EOL care. Many people immediately associate this word with terminal illness, even though it is not defined that way. Offer appropriate explanation and context to avoid triggering negative responses unnecessarily.

listitem.para: Example: “Many people associate the word palliative with end of life, but it just means to provide comfort care. Your pet is not at the end of their life but is an excellent candidate for palliative care to improve and maintain their quality of life.”

blockquote.para: A successful outcome in EOL care is supporting quality of life through to quality of dying in such a manner that patient welfare is attended throughoutand caregivers experience no decisional regret.

sect2.title: 1.3 Psychosocial Considerations
sect2.para: In hospice care, the patient unit includes not just the animal, but also its caregivers. While the needs and welfare of the animal patient are always the first priority, the needs and values of the caregivers are also thoroughly explored and prioritized. This consideration of the caregiver’s perspective is key to a shared decision‐making paradigm. The EOL care team and caregivers are partners who share information and determine the appropriate course of action together (seeSection 1.4). The ideal treatment plan is of no use if the caregivers are not able to implement and maintain the plan. Table 1.1 will help guide technicians through the exploration of the caregiver’s perspective, which will help inform the veterinarian’s individualized care plan.

Caregivers experience a burden of care when supporting their EOL companion animals that can have a significant impact on their own QOL. This burden can be complicated by guilt when a caregiver’s psychosocial concerns impact their ability to care for their pet. Caregivers often experience guilt when they have to make treatment decisions based on their lifestyle and resources rather than purely based on the needs and welfare of their pet. Offering caregivers the opportunity to express their concerns and limitations may help address any guilt about how psychosocial factors must inform treatment choices. Factoring caregiver burden into EOL decision making will be discussed inChapter 8.

sect2.title: 1.4 The Interdisciplinary Team
sect2.para: Veterinary professionals involved in EOL care provide better care for animals and caregivers when they are part of a larger team. The medical needs of the animal and the emotional support needs of the family can be diverse and complex. No one has the capacity or knowledge to be everything to everyone. The establishment of aninterdisciplinary team (IDT) can improve the care provided to animals and families while also reducing burnout and empathic strain in EOL care professionals ch0011-c1-bib-0003. (Empathic strain will be discussed in detail in Chapter 17.)

Table 1.1
Caregiver psychosocial considerations.

entry.para: The physical abilities and limitations of the caregiver should be considered when developing, implementing, and reevaluating EOL care plans. Example: An older adult with osteoarthritis is unable to manage drawing up liquid oral pain medication using a syringe. The veterinarian changes the prescription to a chewable tablet, but the caregiver struggles to open the pill vial for chewable tablets. The technician helps adapt the treatment plan by placing chewable tablets in a resealable bag, out of reach of the pet.

Financial limitations are a valid and important consideration in planning EOL care. They may also change throughout the course of EOL care. The duration of an EOL care plan may be difficult to predict. Caregivers may initially be committed to one care plan, but it may become unsustainable if their circumstances change, or if the pet’s care requirements change. Ensure caregivers feel supported in making decisions within their financial limitations, without judgment. Provide transparent estimates that are forward thinking so that caregivers may plan ahead. Offer opportunities to revisit estimates and financial limitations with any changes to EOL care plans.

Do the caregivers have the time needed to provide the EOL care being discussed? Example: A nurse lives alone with a senior cat that has chronic renal failure and needs insulin injections twice daily. They are struggling to administer the injections due to their hospital schedule. Fortunately, the EOL care team has a few dedicated hospice volunteers who they have trained to provide relief care. The caregiver is grateful to have trained volunteers stop by to feed the cat and administer insulin when required.

The mental and emotional capacity of the caregiver to provide care is an important factor in developing and implementing EOL care plans. Caregivers may initially express no doubt about their capacity to commit to a care plan, but the burden of care may impact their mental and emotional health more than expected. Frequent check‐ins by technicians provide caregivers a chance to express if their mental and emotional capacity is changing.

Caregivers’ spiritual needs are an important consideration as the approach to EOL care is planned. Religious and spiritual beliefs and values may inform much of the decision‐making, particularly when it comes to the EOL transition and aftercare. Technicians can elicit this perspective and ensure it is respected and prioritized in such a way that also ensures animal welfare. Example: A Buddhist caregiver shares with a veterinary technician that they do not wish to consider euthanasia as they feel it goes against their beliefs. The technician offers a referral to a certified hospice and palliative veterinarian to discuss if hospice‐supported natural death will be the right choice for them. They decide to proceed with a hospice‐supported natural death but agree that euthanasia may occur if it is necessary to preserve their pet’s welfare.

sect2.para: An IDT is a group of professionals from multiple disciplines and other stakeholders invested in the patient’s and family’s needs, working together toward a common goal. A team with complementary skill sets and expertise can accomplish more and achieve better outcomes than any member of the team on their own ch0011-c1-bib-0004. While team‐based medicine is common in the veterinary field, the members of the team in EOL care change and multiply to include more disciplines. The veterinarian is generally the leader of the IDT as the medical director for the team. Technicians are core team members, often acting as the “eyes and ears” of the veterinarian by communicating with the client, monitoring the patient, and reporting back to the IDT. The team can include other veterinary professionals, veterinary support staff, other animal care workers, mental health professionals, burial and cremation partners, memorialization partners, volunteers, and more. Table 1.2 lists some common members of IDTs in veterinary EOL care and technicians may be able to identify others that would be valuable on their team.

An IDT may be established to support a dedicated EOL care service, or it may form out of a veterinary team within an existing practice. It is not uncommon for team members to self‐identify as wishing to be part of an EOL care team. These individuals take special interest in further training, education, and responsibility to better serve their EOL clients and patients. Whatever the origins of the EOL care team, the members must demonstrate several aptitudes: excellent empathic communication, nonjudgmental attitudes, flexibility of thinking, professional boundaries, and composure in challenging situationsch0011-c1-bib-0003.
The components of an effective IDT were described by Bronstein (2003) and are listed below:

listitem.para: Interdependence: The members of the team rely on collaboration and communication with the rest of the team to successfully perform their own tasks.
New professional activities: The members of the team work together to offer new services or restructure their services.
Flexibility: The members of the team show adaptability in supporting each other and meeting the needs of the animal and caregivers.
Shared goals: The team takes ownership of creating and striving for the goals of care set forth by the team through shared decision‐making with the animal caregivers.
Reflection: The team actively reflects on their efforts and takes steps to improve.

sect2.title: 1.4.1 Role of Veterinary Technicians
sect2.para: Veterinary technicians have the skills and knowledge to engage in a variety of key roles in an EOL care IDT:

listitem.para: Initial client communication: Obtaining patient history; eliciting the client’s perspective including their values, goals, needs and limitations in providing EOL care

Patient care: Initial patient and environmental assessments, administering prescribed treatments and nursing care, evaluating response to treatment, assessing pain and QOL, diagnostic sample collection and processing
Supervising: Non‐veterinary team members
Educating caregivers: Nursing care and treatment administration, animal behavior and handling, pain and QOL assessments, EOL decision making and planning
Communication liaison: Ongoing client communication and support, updating the veterinarian with changes in patient status or client needs, coordinating referrals and communication with IDT
Lifelong learning and leadership: Engaging in EOL continuing education and helping to educate other members of the IDT

sect2.title: 1.4.2 Role of Veterinary Social Workers
sect2.para: Veterinary social workers are emerging as key members of IDTs in many settings from general practice to referral and emergency facilities. These professionals are invaluable in EOL care and should ideally form the core of the IDT alongside veterinarians and technicians. Veterinary social workers can aid the team in many ways including, but not limited to:

listitem.para: Assessment of the caregiver and family’s psychosocial considerations
Identifying support and service needs and connecting the family with additional resources
Emotional support and counselling of the caregiver and family through EOL decision making and in grief
Conflict identification and resolution within the family and with the veterinary team
Coordination of care with the IDT
Mental health support for members of the IDT

sect2.para: A social worker’s presence in an IDT can greatly improve the quality of support for families, which lessens their anxiety during the EOL journey. In providing this support, the social worker also alleviates the burden on veterinary team members, reducing their risk of empathic strain and burnout. As awareness of the valuable role of social workers in veterinary medicine grows, more practices are hiring social workers as part of their full‐time teams (Pro Tip 1.2).

sidebar.title: Pro Tip 1.2 Prioritizing Access to Veterinary Social Workers
sidebar.para: Veterinary social workers are key members of EOL care teams. Their presence in a team can improve patient outcomes, caregiver satisfaction, and client relationships as well as reducing professional burnout and improving veterinary team efficiency in the face of workforce shortages.

If your veterinary practice does not employ a social worker, try to identify one in your area with an interest in veterinary social work. Ask what services they provide and whether you would be able to refer clients to them when needed.

sect2.title: 1.4.3 Effective Use of Interdisciplinary Teams
sect2.para: The benefits of an IDT can be limited by the availability of other partners and professionals in the community, the finances required to engage with these services, and challenges with ineffective communication between partiesch0011-c1-bib-0004. To be effective, members of an IDT must actively and continuously communicate and collaborate to integrate the care and service provided to the patient unit. This goes well beyond making notes in medical records. One example of effective IDT communication is a technician sending a letter to an emergency clinic outlining the patient history, treatment plan, and goals of care in the event that they are transferred to that facility. Another example would be a technician having a phone conversation with a kennel to discuss the nursing requirements of an EOL patient that will be staying with them.

The members of an IDT within a veterinary facility will meet routinely (weekly is suggested) to discuss new cases, provide patient updates, and debrief on recent deaths. This practice keeps team members informed, encourages active reflection, and presents opportunities to identify areas for improvement (i.e. debriefing on protocols, procedures, communication strategies, and more).

sect2.title: 1.5 Hospice Care Approach
sect2.para: A comprehensive approach to AHPC for EOL patients can be completed in five steps as detailed inTable 1.3. The veterinarian will perform a physical examination of the patient and prescribe the treatment plan while relying on the support of the veterinary technician throughout the five steps.

Hospice patients may be consideredearly hospice when the pet is expected to live for weeks to months, whereas advanced hospice is characterized by an expectation of death within days to weeks. The level of care and communication will vary greatly between these stages, and there may be significant changes in care requirements and caregiver emotional needs as a pet progresses from early to advanced hospice.

sect2.title: 1.6 End‐of‐Life Care Delivery Models
sect2.para: The delivery of EOL care must be flexible to the needs and preferences of the patient and caregiver. The provision of home care is often seen as the ideal service model for animal hospice as it allows the patient to remain in their own home environment. With that said, it is certainly possible to offer AHPC in other business models and there are pros and cons with each. Hospice care can be offered through existing veterinary facilities and integrated into primary care or offered as an ancillary service in a general or specialty veterinary practice. Hospice may be offered in a dedicated business model where it is located in a brick‐and‐mortar hospice center with available mobile units, or it could be offered as an exclusively ambulatory service.

para.emphasis: What are the pros and cons of:
A hospice service in an existing veterinary practice (general or referral/emergency practice)?
A mobile‐only hospice service (solo or multi‐practitioner)?
A dedicated hospice service with its own facility and the capacity to provide mobile service?

sect2.para: Many clients are unaware of the possibilities for AHPC for their pets. They rely on their veterinary teams to guide them, so it is important that AHPC alternatives and home care are discussed as options, even if it is not available through their regular veterinarian. Existing veterinary facilities may refer to other mobile services when requested for home visits, including euthanasia. This is a common way to provide flexibility and options to families beyond what the facility has the capacity to offer. As AHPC becomes more prominent as its own specialized field within veterinary medicine, more clients are seeking flexibility and options, and more veterinary professionals are interested in providing these options. An existing veterinary facility may establish its own mobile unit to expand the EOL care services it offers to include home care. This could be limited to home euthanasia or could be expanded to include home hospice consultations and care plans (seePro Tip 1.3 and 1.4).

A veterinary facility seeking to offer more dedicated EOL care services must consider how it will handle emergency calls. Is the facility already open 24 hours a day and 7 days a week, or will the hospice clients have access to an on‐call member of the veterinary team? Will hospice clients be expected to contact an emergency facility outside of regular business hours? How will clients be supported if the hospice veterinarian is away? Is there another EOL care service in that area that can act as a partner to cover periods of absence?

sect2.title: 1.6.1 Role of Telemedicine
sect2.para: Telemedicine, or telehealth, can be a powerful tool to support caregivers and pets, but it must be used cautiously to ensure proper establishment and maintenance of the veterinary–client–patient relationship (VCPR). Telemedicine can be used in many ways:

listitem.para: Initial history taking
Eliciting client perspective prior to in‐person consultation
Disease and treatment plan education

Follow‐up after consultationsPro Tip 1.3 Benefits of Home Hospice Consultations
Hospice consultations should be conducted in the home environment whenever possible for multiple reasons:
Pro Tip 1.4 Mobile Service Record Keeping
Cloud‐based medical records are highly useful when offering mobile care.
Care plan monitoring
Follow‐up after treatment changes
Clinical sign tracking
Confirm the need for an in‐person visit for further evaluation
QOL consultations
Revising goals of care
Emotional support for the caregivers
EOL planning

sect2.para: The benefits of appropriately implemented telemedicine can include:

listitem.para: Improved rapport and relationship building with caregivers
Reduced caregiver anxiety and burden with increased access to support
Real time updates on patient clinical signs
Improved treatment compliance
Improved access to and convenience of care for clients
Reduced patient anxiety by minimizing in‐person visits
Improved patient comfort with faster evaluation and response to changes
More efficient use of resources in the face of workforce shortages

sect2.para: Telemedicine services must be structured so that the time spent is somehow compensated. Each facility will identify its own approach, and often multiple approaches are advised to fit different situations (e.g. different fees for technician vs. veterinarian telemedicine support). Fee structures may include direct charges for telemedicine consultations, inclusion of telemedicine follow‐up in initial consultation fees, or even hospice care service packages with a defined amount of telemedicine support included for a pre‐paid fee. The author has found the service plans to be utilized most in advanced hospice situations where a high level of support is needed regularly (i.e. daily). Caregivers outside of advanced hospice are generally happy to pay a fee for telemedicine support as needed and see the value of this service (Pro Tip 1.5).

Telemedicine is most readily used within existing VCPRs but can sometimes be used in other situations. Veterinary practices may consider offering telemedicine QOL consultation for non‐clients provided no treatment recommendations are made in this context. This will differ significantly from a consultation within a VCPR, and the client must be made explicitly aware of the limitations at the outset. This consultation is structured as a guided exploration of QOL concepts with probing questions to help the caregiver consider their animal’s individual context. At the consultation's end, the client would either be referred back to their regular veterinarian or asked to schedule an appointment to establish a VCPR before any treatments could be prescribed.

sidebar.title: Pro Tip 1.5 The Valuation of Telemedicine
sidebar.para: Telemedicine consultations provide valuable connections between caregivers and the veterinary team, particularly for offering QOL consultation and support advanced hospice caregivers. Clients recognize the value of this service and the need for compensation to support its sustainability within a veterinary business.

Identify a fee structure that allows the time devoted to telemedicine for your EOL care clients to be a sustainable part of your practice. Communicate clearly about fees in advance to prevent confusion or conflict over costs.

sect2.title: 1.6.2 Informed Consent and Liability Considerations
sect2.para: The delivery of comprehensive animal hospice care can present some additional challenges compared to more traditional veterinary practice. Unique liability concerns must be considered (e.g. dispensing of controlled drugs for use at home) and detailed documentation of informed consent is recommended (i.e. hospice‐supported natural death). Many of the challenges that can arise in EOL care are prevented or proactively managed with clear communication regarding caregiver expectations, roles, and responsibilities, and the limitations and professional boundaries of the veterinary team.

Veterinary teams that offer more dedicated EOL care services may wish to update their existing euthanasia consent forms and add additional informed consent documentation such as a hospice care agreement. Topics that should be addressed in a hospice care agreement are listed below, and many will be discussed further in later chapters.

listitem.para: Expectations and contacts for access to 24‐hour care and emergency services
Expectations and plans for follow‐up and monitoring including fees
Fees for ancillary services such as telemedicine support
Client responsibilities in the provision of care and communication with the hospice team
Client responsibilities in the possession and handling of controlled drugs
Expectations for death, particularly hospice‐supported natural death (including a provision to proceed to humane euthanasia if required to address animal welfare)
A provision for termination of the veterinary‐client‐patient relationship if the veterinary team and client are unable to agree on an ethical course of action
Successful EOL care reduces caregiver decisional regret.
Effectively addressing patient and caregiver needs in a sustainable manner requires an IDT, which ideally includes a veterinary social worker.
Hospice care includes evaluation of the caregiver’s perspective, disease education, development and implementation of an individualized care plan, follow‐up, and adjustments.
Animal hospice can be offered in multiple business models, and consideration should be given to mobile units, telemedicine services, informed consent, and liability concerns.
EOL care teams must communicate with caregivers clearly regarding expectations, roles, responsibilities, and boundaries.
